sections.heading: 14 Abstract
sections.text:
15 In this paper, we report Na3BiO4 - Bi2O3 mixed oxide nanoplates 16 for carbon dioxide gas sensing applications. These nanoplates have 17 been synthesized using electrochemical deposition with potentiostatic 18 mode on ITO substrate and characterized using scanning electron 19 microscopy (SEM) & X-ray diffraction (XRD) to analyze their surface 20 morphology and structure. SEM study shows the presence of hori21 zontally aligned nanoplates stacked on top of one another (thickness 22 40 nm to 75 nm). XRD pattern shows the presence of mono23 clinic Na3BiO4 and Bi2O3. The gas percentage response is evaluated 24 by measuring the change in electrical resistance of the nanoplates in 25 the presence of carbon dioxide for different pressures at 50◦C, 75◦C 26 and 100◦C. Percentage response of more than 100 % is seen at 30 27 psi gas pressure which increases to ≈ 277 % at 90 psi at 100◦C.

sections.heading: 30 1 Introduction
sections.text:
31 Modern industrialized society possess a great threat to our safety and well 32 being, mainly due to the release of green house gases like carbon dioxide. 33 These gases are responsible for the unstable environmental phenomenons like
34 droughts and famines Dimitriou et al (2021); Shahbazi et al (2021).
35 36 A lot of environmental friendly compounds are being explored for their 37 possible application in solid state gas sensors. Metal oxide semiconductors, 38 carbon nanotubes based composites are few examples of materials that show 39 good potential for sensing Barsan et al (2007); Rai et al (2014); Philip et al 40 (2003); Rai et al (2015). Low cost, high sensitivity and quick response time 41 makes the sensors based on metal oxide semiconductors very attractive. Bis42 muth oxide is environmental friendly and are known to show good sensitivity 43 with a large number of gases like CO2, NO2 and NO Bhande et al (2011); 44 Gou et al (2009); Cabot et al (2004).
45 46 Metal oxide semiconductor based sensors mainly work by adsorption and 47 desorption of gas on the surface causing a change in their electrical resistance 48 Fine et al (2010); Seiyama et al (1962). Thus a large surface area is highly 49 desirable for a good sensor. Nanostructures provides an ideal way of achieving 50 this and their morphology has a direct impact on the gas sensing behaviour 51 of the material Gurlo (2011). In this paper, horizontally aligned nanoplates of 52 Na3BiO4 - Bi2O3 mixed oxide have been synthesized using potentiostatic elec53 trodeposition and their CO2 sensing properties have been studied at different 54 pressures.

sections.heading: 72 2.3 Sensor setup
sections.text:
73 A chemiresistor type sensor has been prepared for studying the gas sensing 74 behavior of these nanoplates (figure 1). The nanoplates are deposited on to 75 the ITO substrate using potentiostatic electrodeposition. After drying at room 76 temperature, two leads of copper wire were attached using silver paste. This 77 sensor was then installed inside a homemade stainless steel gas sensing cham78 ber (figure 2). Keithley sourcemeter (2601B) was connected to the sample for 79 resistance measurement at a constant current of 10 mA. Keithley power sup80 ply (2600B-250-4 360W) and a Keithley digital multimeter (2700) were used 81 to power the heater and measure the temperature inside the chamber. Inlet 82 and outlet valves were installed to inject and release the gas from the cham83 ber. Chamber pressure was measured with the help of pressure meter fitted at 84 the top of the chamber. CO2 gas was introduced from a pressurized cylinder 85 (100 % CO2).

X-Ray diffraction pattern shows that the prepared sample is polycrystalline in nature (figure 5). Major diffraction peaks correspond to Na3BiO4 (JCPDS 01- 071-1583) and Bi2O3 (JCPDS 00-041-1449). Both the oxide phases Na3BiO4 and Bi2O3 exhibit monoclinic structure. Semiquantitative concentration analysis (PANalytical X’pert Highscore) shows that the relative fraction of Na3BiO4 and Bi2O3 phases are 20 % and 80 % respectively.

sections.heading: 3.4 Gas sensing
sections.text:
The percentage response of the Na3BiO4 - Bi2O3 mixed oxide nanoplates towards CO2 was determined by measuring the change in resistance of the sample on exposure to carbon dioxide using the formula: Response (%) = ((Ro-Rg)/Rg)*100 Rella et al (1997). Ro is the resistance of sample in presence of air while Rg is the resistance in presence of CO2 gas. These measurements were initially carried out at 90 psi CO2 pressure for 50◦ C, 75◦ C and 100◦ C (figure 6). At first, CO2 gas was flushed trough the chamber to remove the air present in the chamber. The output valve was then closed and the required CO2 pressure was built up (indicated by CO2 ON). In the third step (indicated by CO2 OFF), inlet valve was closed and the outlet valve was opened to release the CO2 pressure. Percentage response of 0%, 15.5% and 276.8 % was seen at 50◦ C, 75◦ C and 100◦ C respectively.

Highest percentage response value of 276.8 % is obtained at 90 psi, which decreases to 254.5 % & 116.5 % at 60 psi and 30 psi respectively for Na3BiO4 - Bi2O3 mixed oxide nanoplates. Response time increases (250 ms at 90 psi, 500 ms at 60 psi & 650 ms at 30 psi) while recovery time decreases (78 s at 90 psi, 53.5 s at 60 psi & 24.5 s at 30 psi) as the pressure is decreased from 90 psi to 30 psi This may be due to deeper adsorption of gas molecules at higher pressures. Bi2O3 nanoplates prepared by the similar route do not show significant percentage response (3.5 % at 100◦ C and 90 psi gas pressure) while ITO substrate shows no sensitivity at all. To further analyze the relationship between CO2 pressure and percentage response, a linear fit is plotted (figure 9). A sensitivity of 3.2 %/psi is seen (R2 = 0.94).

The gas sensing mechanism can be explained by taking into account the interaction of CO2 with the surface nanoplates (figure 11). An almost instantaneous decrease in resistance is seen on exposure to CO2 gas.
When the heated metal oxide nanoplates are exposed to air, oxygen gets adsorbed on the surface. At temperatures < 150◦ C, oxygen is predominantly adsorbed as O2− Ranwa et al (2014). The detailed mechanism can be explained with the help of following equations:
O2 (air) −→ O2 (adsorbed)
(1)
O2 (adsorbed) + 2e−−→ 2O2−
(2)

In this process, oxygen takes up electrons from the conduction band. This leads to the formation of an electron depletion layer for an n-type material or a hole accumulation layer for a p-type material. When an oxidizing gas like CO2 gas is introduced on to a n-type metal oxide semiconductor surface, the gas molecules gets adsorbed onto the surface of the material by taking up free electrons. The mechanism of CO2 adsorption can be understood with the help of following equations Bhande et al (2011):

CO2 breaks up into CO and O on surface interaction. The oxygen atoms released takes up electrons from the surface forming O2−. This causes a further expansion of electron depletion layer which in turn causes a decrease in conductivity. However when a p-type material is involved, CO2 causes an expansion of hole accumulation layer thereby causing an increase in conduc- tivity or decrease in resistance Hung et al (2017).
In the present work, a significant decrease in resistance is observed for Na3BiO4 - Bi2O3 mixed oxide nanoplates on introduction of CO2 gas (figure 11). This suggests that this material is behaving as a strong p-type semicon- ductor (figure 12). Nanoplates offer a very large surface area leading to good adsorption. Results suggests that this adsorption is reversible and the original conductivity of the material is restored after the gas is removed.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text:
Na3BiO4 - Bi2O3 mixed oxide nanostructures have been synthesized using potentiostatic electrodeposition. XRD analysis shows peaks corrsponding to monoclinic Na3BiO4 and Bi2O3 with weight percentage of 20 % and 80 % respectively. SEM studies reveals the presence of horizontally aligned nanoplates with thickness ranging from 40 nm to 75 nm. The percentage response shows a linear dependance on pressure in the range 0 psi to 90 psi and 100◦ C (R2 = 0.94). A sensitivity of 3.2 %/psi is observed. These mixed oxide nanoplates shows a very quick response to CO2 gas, which is a highly sought after characteristic for a gas sensor. Repeatability and stability makes this material an ideal candidate for sensor development.
